NELSON.rule_desc: <param1> point is more than 3 standard deviations from the mean.
<param1> (or more) points in a row are on the same side of the mean.
<param1> (or more) points in a row are continually increasing (or decreasing).
<param1> (or more) points in a row alternate in direction, increasing then decreasing.
<param1> (or <param3>) out of <param2> points in a row are more than 2 standard deviations from the mean in the same direction.
<param1> (or <param3>) out of <param2> points in a row are more than 1 standard deviation from the mean in the same direction.
<param1> points in a row are all within 1 standard deviation of the mean on either side of the mean.
<param1> points in a row exist, but none within 1 standard deviation of the mean, and the points are in both directions from the mean.

WECO.rule_desc: Any <param1> data point falls outside the 3Ïƒ-limit from the centerline (i.e., any point that falls outside Zone A, beyond either the upper or lower control limit)
<param1> out of <param2> consecutive points fall beyond the 2Ïƒ-limit (in zone A or beyond), on the same side of the centerline
<param1> out of <param2> consecutive points fall beyond the 1Ïƒ-limit (in zone B or beyond), on the same side of the centerline
<param1> consecutive points fall on the same side of the centerline (in zone C or beyond)

WESTGARD.rule_desc: <param1> measurement exceeds 2 standard deviations either above or below the mean of the reference range.
<param1> measurement exceeds 3 standard deviations either above or below the mean of the reference range.
<param1> consecutive measurements are on the same side of the mean.
<param1> consecutive measurements exceed 2 standard deviations of the reference range, and on the same side of the mean.
<param1> consecutive measurements exceed 1 standard deviation on the same side of the mean.
<param1> measurements in the same run have a 4 standard deviation difference (such as one exceeding 2 standard deviations above the mean, and another exceeding 2 standard deviations below the mean).
